content.28: Chi-gwisa-miti was taller than either of his brothers, but Makoma was not afraid, and called out to him: "Who are you, O Big One?"	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.29: "I," said the giant, "am Chi-gwisa-miti, and I am planting these bao-babs and thorns as food for my children the elephants."	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.30: "Leave off!" shouted the hero, "for I am Makoma, and would like to exchange a blow with thee!"	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.31: The giant, plucking up a monster bao-bab by the roots, struck heavily at Makoma;|but the hero sprang aside, and as the weapon sank deep into the soft earth, whirled Nu-endo the hammer round his head and felled the giant with one blow.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.32: So terrible was the stroke that Chi-gwisa-miti shrivelled up as the other giants had done;|and when he had got back his breath he begged Makoma to take him as his servant.|"For," said he, "it is honourable to serve a man so great as thou."	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.33: Makoma, after placing him in his sack, proceeded upon his journey, and travelling for many days he at last reached a country so barren and rocky that not a single living thing grew upon it -- everywhere reigned grim desolation.|And in the midst of this dead region he found a man eating fire.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.34: "What are you doing?" demanded Makoma.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.35: "I am eating fire," answered the man, laughing; "and my name is Chi-idea-moto, for I am the flame-spirit, and can waste and destroy what I like."	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.36: "You are wrong," said Makoma; "for I am Makoma, who is 'greater' than you -- and you cannot destroy me!"	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.37: The fire-eater laughed again, and blew a flame at Makoma.|But the hero sprang behind a rock -- just in time, for the ground upon which he had been standing was turned to molten glass, like an overbaked pot, by the heat of the flame-spirit's breath.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.38: Then the hero flung his iron hammer at Chi-idea-moto, and, striking him, it knocked him helpless;|so Makoma placed him in the sack, Woro-nowu, with the other great men that he had overcome.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.39: And now, truly, Makoma was a very great hero;|for he had the strength to make hills, the industry to lead rivers over dry wastes, foresight and wisdom in planting trees, and the power of producing fire when he wished.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.40: Wandering on he arrived one day at a great plain, well watered and full of game;|and in the very middle of it, close to a large river, was a grassy spot, very pleasant to make a home upon.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.41: Makoma was so delighted with the little meadow that he sat down under a large tree and removing the sack from his shoulder, took out all the giants and set them before him.|"My friends," said he, "I have travelled far and am weary.|Is not this such a place as would suit a hero for his home?|Let us then go, to-morrow, to bring in timber to make a kraal."	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.42: So the next day Makoma and the giants set out to get poles to build the kraal, leaving only Chi-eswa-mapiri to look after the place and cook some venison which they had killed.|In the evening, when they returned, they found the giant helpless and tied to a tree by one enormous hair!	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.43: "How is it," said Makoma, astonished, "that we find you thus bound and helpless?"	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.44: "O Chief," answered Chi-eswa-mapiri, "at mid-day a man came out of the river;|he was of immense statue, and his grey moustaches were of such length that I could not see where they ended!|He demanded of me 'Who is thy master?'|And I answered: 'Makoma, the greatest of heroes.'|Then the man seized me, and pulling a hair from his moustache, tied me to this tree -- even as you see me."	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.45: Makoma was very wroth, but he said nothing, and drawing his finger-nail across the hair (which was as thick and strong as palm rope) cut it, and set free the mountain-maker.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.46: The three following days exactly the same thing happened, only each time with a different one of the party;|and on the fourth day Makoma stayed in camp when the others went to cut poles, saying that he would see for himself what sort of man this was that lived in the river and whose moustaches were so long that they extended beyond men's sight.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.47: So when the giants had gone he swept and tidied the camp and put some venison on the fire to roast.|At midday, when the sun was right overhead, he heard a rumbling noise from the river, and looking up he saw the head and shoulders of an enormous man emerging from it.|And behold! right down the river-bed and up the river-bed, till they faded into the blue distance, stretched the giant's grey moustaches!	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.48: "Who are you?" bellowed the giant, as soon as he was out of the water.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.49: "I am he that is called Makoma," answered the hero;|"and, before I slay thee, tell me also what is thy name and what thou doest in the river?"	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.50: "My name is Chin-debou Mau-giri," said the giant.|"My home is in the river, for my moustache is the grey fever-mist that hangs above the water, and with which I bind all those that come unto me so that they die."	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.51: "You cannot bind me!" shouted Makoma, rushing upon him and striking with his hammer.|But the river giant was so slimy that the blow slid harmlessly off his green chest, and as Makoma stumbled and tried to regain his balance, the giant swung one of his long hairs around him and tripped him up.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.52: For a moment Makoma was helpless, but remembering the power of the flame-spirit which had entered into him, he breathed a fiery breath upon the giant's hair and cut himself free.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.53: As Chin-debou Mau-giri leaned forward to seize him the hero flung his sack Woronowu over the giant's slippery head, and gripping his iron hammer, struck him again;|this time the blow alighted upon the dry sack and Chin-debou Mau-giri fell dead.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.54: When the four giants returned at sunset with the poles, they rejoiced to find that Makoma had overcome the fever-spirit, and they feasted on the roast venison till far into the night;|but in the morning, when they awoke, Makoma was already warming his hands to the fire, and his face was gloomy.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.55: "In the darkness of the night, O my friends," he said presently, "the white spirits of my fathers came upon me and spoke, saying: 'Get thee hence, Makoma, for thou shalt have no rest until thou hast found and fought with Sakatirina, who had five heads, and is very great and strong;|so take leave of thy friends, for thou must go alone.'"	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.56: Then the giants were very sad, and bewailed the loss of their hero;|but Makoma comforted them, and gave back to each the gifts he had taken from them.|Then bidding them "Farewell," he went on his way.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.57: Makoma travelled far towards the west;|over rough mountains and water-logged morasses, fording deep rivers, and tramping for days across dry deserts where most men would have died, until at length he arrived at a hut standing near some large peaks, and inside the hut were two beautiful women.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.58: "Greeting!" said the hero.|"Is this the country of Sakatirina of five heads, whom I am seeking?"	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.59: "We greet you, O Great One!" answered the women.|"We are the wives of Sakatirina;|your search is at an end, for there stands he whom you seek!"|And they pointed to what Makoma had thought were two tall mountain peaks.|"Those are his legs," they said; "his body you cannot see, for it is hidden in the clouds."	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.60: Makoma was astonished when he beheld how tall was the giant;|but, nothing daunted, he went forward until he reached one of Sakatirina's legs, which he struck heavily with Nu-endo.|Nothing happened, so he hit again and then again until, presently, he heard a tired, far-away voice saying: "Who is it that scratches my feet?"	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.61: And Makoma shouted as loud as he could, answering: "It is I, Makoma, who is called 'Greater'!"|And he listened, but there was no answer.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.62: Then Makoma collected all the dead brushwood and trees that he could find, and making an enormous pile round the giant's legs, set a light to it.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.63: This time the giant spoke;|his voice was very terrible, for it was the rumble of thunder in the clouds.|"Who is it," he said, "making that fire smoulder around my feet?"	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.64: "It is I, Makoma!" shouted the hero.|"And I have come from far away to see thee, O Sakatirina, for the spirits of my fathers bade me go seek and fight with thee, lest I should grow fat, and weary of myself."	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.65: There was silence for a while, and then the giant spoke softly: "It is good, O Makoma!" he said.|"For I too have grown weary.|There is no man so great as I, therefore I am all alone.|Guard thyself!" and bending suddenly he seized the hero in his hands and dashed him upon the ground.|And lo! instead of death, Makoma had found life, for he sprang to his feet mightier in strength and stature than before, and rushing in he gripped the giant by the waist and wrestled with him.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.66: Hour by hour they fought, and mountains rolled beneath their feet like pebbles in a flood;|now Makoma would break away, and summoning up his strength, strike the giant with Nu-endo his iron hammer, and Sakatirina would pluck up the mountains and hurl them upon the hero, but neither one could slay the other.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.67: At last, upon the second day, they grappled so strongly that they could not break away;|but their strength was failing, and, just as the sun was sinking, they fell together to the ground, insensible.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.68: In the morning when they awoke, Mulimo the Great Spirit was standing by them;|and he said: "O Makoma and Sakatirina!|Ye are heroes so great that no man may come against you.|Therefore ye will leave the world and take up your home with me in the clouds."|And as he spake the heroes became invisible to the people of the Earth, and were no more seen among them.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.69: From the Senna (Oral Tradition), Native Rhodesian Tale.	The Story of the Hero Makoma	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.70: The Magic Mirror	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.71: by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.72: A long, long while ago, before ever the White Men were seen in Senna, there lived a man called Gopani-Kufa.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.73: One day, as he was out hunting, he came upon a strange sight.|An enormous python had caught an antelope and coiled itself around it;|the antelope, striking out in despair with its horns, had pinned the python's neck to a tree, and so deeply had its horns sunk in the soft wood that neither creature could get away.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.74: "Help!" cried the antelope, "for I was doing no harm, yet I have been caught, and would have been eaten, had I not defended myself."	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.75: "Help me," said the python, "for I am Insato, King of all the Reptiles, and will reward you well!"	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.76: Gopani-Kufa considered for a moment, then stabbing the antelope with his assegai, he set the python free.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.77: "I thank you," said the python; "come back here with the new moon, when I shall have eaten the antelope, and I will reward you as I promised."	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.78: "Yes," said the dying antelope, "he will reward you, and lo! your reward shall be your own undoing!"	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.79: Gopani-Kufa went back to his kraal, and with the new moon he returned again to the spot where he had saved the python.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.80: Insato was lying upon the ground, still sleepy from the effects of his huge meal, and when he saw the man he thanked him again, and said: "Come with me now to Pita, which is my own country, and I will give you what you will of all my possessions."	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.81: Gopani-Kufa at first was afraid, thinking of what the antelope had said, but finally he consented and followed Insato into the forest.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.82: For several days they travelled, and at last they came to a hole leading deep into the earth.|It was not very wide, but large enough to admit a man.|"Hold on to my tail," said Insato, "and I will go down first, drawing you after me."|The man did so, and Insato entered.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.83: Down, down, down they went for days, all the while getting deeper and deeper into the earth, until at last the darkness ended and they dropped into a beautiful country;|around them grew short green grass, on which browsed herds of cattle and sheep and goats.|In the distance Gopani-Kufa saw a great collection of houses all square, built of stone and very tall, and their roofs were shining with gold and burnished iron.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.84: Gopani-Kufa turned to Insato, but found, in the place of the python, a man, strong and handsome, with the great snake's skin wrapped round him for covering;|and on his arms and neck were rings of pure gold.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.85: The man smiled.|"I am Insato," said he, "but in my own country I take man's shape -- even as you see me -- for this is Pita, the land over which I am king."|He then took Gopani-Kufa by the hand and led him towards the town.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.86: On the way they passed rivers in which men and women were bathing and fishing and boating;|and farther on they came to gardens covered with heavy crops of rice and maize, and many other grains which Gopani-Kufa did not even know the name of.|And as they passed, the people who were singing at their work in the fields, abandoned their labours and saluted Insato with delight, bringing also palm wine and green cocoanuts for refreshment, as to one returned from a long journey.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.87: "These are my children!" said Insato, waving his hand towards the people.|Gopani-Kufa was much astonished at all that he saw, but he said nothing.|Presently they came to the town;|everything here, too, was beautiful, and everything that a man might desire he could obtain.|Even the grains of dust in the streets were of gold and silver.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.88: Insato conducted Gopani-Kufa to the palace, and showing him his rooms, and the maidens who would wait upon him, told him that they would have a great feast that night, and on the morrow he might name his choice of the riches of Pita and it should be given him.|Then he was away.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.89: Now Gopani-Kufa had a wasp called Zengi-mizi.|Zengi-mizi was not an ordinary wasp, for the spirit of the father of Gopani-Kufa had entered it, so that it was exceedingly wise.|In times of doubt Gopani-Kufa always consulted the wasp as to what had better be done, so on this occasion he took it out of the little rush basket in which he carried it, saying: "Zengi-mizi, what gift shall I ask of Insato to-morrow when he would know the reward he shall bestow on me for saving his life?"	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.90: "Biz-z-z," hummed Zengi-mizi, "ask him for Sipao the Mirror."|And it flew back into its basket.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.91: Gopani-Kufa was astonished at this answer;|but knowing that the words of Zengi-mizi were true words, he determined to make the request.|So that night they feasted, and on the morrow Insato came to Gopani-Kufa and, giving him greeting joyfully, he said: "Now, O my friend, name your choice amongst my possessions and you shall have it!"	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.92: "O king!" answered Gopani-Kufa, "out of all your possessions I will have the Mirror, Sipao."	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.93: The king started.|"O friend, Gopani-Kufa," he said, "ask anything but that!|I did not think that you would request that which is most precious to me."	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.94: "Let me think over it again then, O king," said Gopani-Kufa, "and to-morrow I will let you know if I change my mind."	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.95: But the king was still much troubled, fearing the loss of Sipao, for the mirror had magic powers, so that he who owned it had but to ask and his wish would be fulfilled;|to it Insato owed all that he possessed.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.96: As soon as the king left him, Gopani-Kufa again took Zengi-mizi, out of his basket.|"Zengi-mizi," he said, "the king seems loth to grant my request for the Mirror -- is there not some other thing of equal value for which I might ask?"	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.97: And the wasp answered: "There is nothing in the world, O Gopani-Kufa, which is of such value as this Mirror, for it is a Wishing Mirror, and accomplishes the desires of him who owns it.|If the king hesitates, go to him the next day, and the day after, and in the end he will bestow the Mirror upon you, for you saved his life."	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.98: And it was even so.|For three days Gopani-Kufa returned the same answer to the king, and, at last, with tears in his eyes, Insato gave him the Mirror, which was of polished iron, saying: "Take Sipao, then, O Gopani-Kufa, and may thy wishes come true.|Go back now to thine own country;|Sipao will show you the way."	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.99: Gopani-Kufa was greatly rejoiced, and, taking farewell of the king, said to the Mirror: "Sipao, Sipao, I wish to be back upon the Earth again!"	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.100: Instantly he found himself standing upon the upper earth;|but, not knowing the spot, he said again to the Mirror: "Sipao, Sipao, I want the path to my own kraal!"	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.101: And behold! right before him lay the path!	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.102: When he arrived home he found his wife and daughter mourning for him, for they thought that he had been eaten by lions;|but he comforted them, saying that while following a wounded antelope he had missed his way and had wandered for a long time before he had found the path again.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.103: That night he asked Zengi-mizi, in whom sat the spirit of his father, what he had better ask Sipao for next?	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.104: "Biz-z-z," said the wasp, "would you not like to be as great a chief as Insato?"	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.105: And Gopani-Kufa smiled, and took the Mirror and said to it: "Sipao, Sipao, I want a town as great as that of Insato, the King of Pita;|and I wish to be chief over it!"	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.106: Then all along the banks of the Zambesi river, which flowed near by, sprang up streets of stone buildings, and their roofs shone with gold and burnished iron like those in Pita;|and in the streets men and women were walking, and young boys were driving out the sheep and cattle to pasture;|and from the river came shouts and laughter from the young men and maidens who had launched their canoes and were fishing.|And when the people of the new town beheld Gopani-Kufa they rejoiced greatly and hailed him as chief.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.107: Gopani-Kufa was now as powerful as Insato the King of the Reptiles had been, and he and his family moved into the palace that stood high above the other buildings right in the middle of the town.|His wife was too astonished at all these wonders to ask any questions, but his daughter Shasasa kept begging him to tell her how he had suddenly become so great;|so at last he revealed the whole secret, and even entrusted Sipao the Mirror to her care, saying: "It will be safer with you, my daughter, for you dwell apart;|whereas men come to consult me on affairs of state, and the Mirror might be stolen."	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.108: Then Shasasa took the Magic Mirror and hid it beneath her pillow, and after that for many years Gopani-Kufa ruled his people both well and wisely, so that all men loved him, and never once did he need to ask Sipao to grant him a wish.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.109: Now it happened that, after many years, when the hair of Gopani-Kufa was turning grey with age, there came white men to that country.|Up the Zambesi they came, and they fought long and fiercely with Gopani-Kufa;|but, because of the power of the Magic Mirror, he beat them, and they fled to the sea-coast.|Chief among them was one Rei, a man of much cunning, who sought to discover whence sprang Gopani-Kufa's power.|So one day he called to him a trusty servant named Butou, and said: "Go you to the town and find out for me what is the secret of its greatness."	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.110: And Butou, dressing himself in rags, set out, and when he came to Gopani-Kufa's town he asked for the chief;|and the people took him into the presence of Gopani-Kufa.|When the white man saw him he humbled himself, and said: "O Chief! take pity on me, for I have no home!|When Rei marched against you I alone stood apart, for I knew that all the strength of the Zambesi lay in your hands, and because I would not fight against you he turned me forth into the forest to starve!"	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.111: And Gopani-Kufa believed the white man's story, and he took him in and feasted him, and gave him a house.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.112: In this way the end came.|For the heart of Shasasa, the daughter of Gopani-Kufa, went forth to Butou the traitor, and from her he learnt the secret of the Magic Mirror.|One night, when all the town slept, he felt beneath her pillow and, finding the Mirror, he stole it and fled back with it to Rei, the chief of the white men.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.113: So it befell that, one day, as Gopani-Kufa was gazing up at the river from a window of the palace he again saw the war-canoes of the white men;|and at the sight his spirit misgave him.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.114: "Shasasa! my daughter!" he cried wildly, "go fetch me the mirror, for the white men are at hand."	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.115: "Woe is me, my father!" she sobbed.|"The Mirror is gone!|For I loved Butou the traitor, and he has stolen Sipao from me!"|Then Gopani-Kufa calmed himself, and drew out Zengi-mizi from its rush basket.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.116: "O spirit of my father!" he said, "what now shall I do?"	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.117: "O Gopani-Kufa!" hummed the wasp, "there is nothing now that can be done, for the words of the antelope which you slew are being fulfilled."	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.118: "Alas! I am an old man -- I had forgotten!" cried the chief.|"The words of the antelope were true words -- my reward shall be my undoing -- they are being fulfilled!"	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.119: Then the white men fell upon the people of Gopani-Kufa and slew them together with the chief and his daughter Shasasa;|and since then all the power of the Earth has rested in the hands of the white men, for they have in their possession Sipao, the Magic Mirror.	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.120: From the Senna	The Magic Mirror	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.121: Story of the King Who Would See Paradise	Story of the King Who Would See Paradise	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.122: by Andrew Lang, 1906	Story of the King Who Would See Paradise	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.123: Once upon a time there was king who, one day out hunting, came upon a fakeer in a lonely place in the mountains.|The fakeer was seated on a little old bedstead reading the Koran, with his patched cloak thrown over his shoulders.	Story of the King Who Would See Paradise	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.124: The king asked him what he was reading;|and he said he was reading about Paradise, and praying that he might be worthy to enter there.|Then they began to talk, and, by-and-bye, the king asked the fakeer if he could show him a glimpse of Paradise, for he found it very difficult to believe in what he could not see.|The fakeer replied that he was asking a very difficult, and perhaps a very dangerous, thing;|but that he would pray for him, and perhaps he might be able to do it;|only he warned the king both against the dangers of his unbelief, and against the curiosity which prompted him to ask this thing.|However, the king was not to be turned from his purpose, and he promised the fakeer always to provided him with food, if he, in return, would pray for him.|To this the fakeer agreed, and so they parted.	Story of the King Who Would See Paradise	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.125: Time went on, and the king always sent the old fakeer his food according to his promise;|but, whenever he sent to ask him when he was going to show him Paradise, the fakeer always replied: "Not yet, not yet!"	Story of the King Who Would See Paradise	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.126: After a year or two had passed by, the king heard one day that the fakeer was very ill -- indeed, he was believed to be dying.|Instantly he hurried off himself, and found that it was really true, and that the fakeer was even then breathing his last.|There and then the king besought him to remember his promise, and to show him a glimpse of Paradise.|The dying fakeer replied that if the king would come to his funeral, and, when the grave was filled in, and everyone else was gone away, he would come and lay his hand upon the grave, he would keep his word, and show him a glimpse of Paradise.|At the same time he implored the king not to do this thing, but to be content to see Paradise when God called him there.|Still the king's curiosity was so aroused that he would not give way.	Story of the King Who Would See Paradise	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.127: Accordingly, after the fakeer was dead, and had been buried, he stayed behind when all the rest went away;|and then, when he was quite alone, he stepped forward, and laid his hand upon the grave!|Instantly the ground opened, and the astonished king, peeping in, saw a flight of rough steps, and, at the bottom of them, the fakeer sitting, just as he used to sit, on his rickety bedstead, reading the Koran!	Story of the King Who Would See Paradise	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.128: At first the king was so surprised and frightened that he could only stare;|but the fakeer beckoned to him to come down, so, mustering up his courage, he boldly stepped down into the grave.	Story of the King Who Would See Paradise	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.129: The fakeer rose, and, making a sign to the king to follow, walked a few paces along a dark passage.|Then he stopped, turned solemnly to his companion, and, with a movement of his hand, drew aside as it were a heavy curtain, and revealed -- what?|No one knows what was there shown to the king, nor did he ever tell anyone;|but, when the fakeer at length dropped the curtain, and the king turned to leave the place, he had had his glimpse of Paradise!|Trembling in every limb, he staggered back along the passage, and stumbled up the steps out of the tomb into the fresh air again.	Story of the King Who Would See Paradise	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.130: The dawn was breaking.|It seemed odd to the king that he had been so long in the grave.|It appeared but a few minutes ago that he had descended, passed along a few steps to the place where he had peeped beyond the veil, and returned again after perhaps five minutes of that wonderful view!|And what WAS it he had seen?|He racked his brains to remember, but he could not call to mind a single thing!|How curious everything looked too!|Why, his own city, which by now he was entering, seemed changed and strange to him!	Story of the King Who Would See Paradise	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.131: The sun was already up when he turned into the palace gate and entered the public durbar hall.|It was full;|and there upon the throne sat another king!|The poor king, all bewildered, sat down and stared about him.|Presently a chamberlain came across and asked him why he sat unbidden in the king's presence.	Story of the King Who Would See Paradise	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.132: "But I am the king!" he cried.	Story of the King Who Would See Paradise	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.133: "What king?" said the chamberlain.	Story of the King Who Would See Paradise	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.134: "The true king of this country," said he indignantly.	Story of the King Who Would See Paradise	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.135: Then the chamberlain went away, and spoke to the king who sat on the throne, and the old king heard words like "mad," "age," "compassion."|Then the king on the throne called him to come forward, and, as he went, he caught sight of himself reflected in the polished steel shield of the bodyguard, and started back in horror!|He was old, decrepit, dirty, and ragged!|His long white beard and locks were unkempt, and straggled all over his chest and shoulders.|Only one sign of royalty remained to him, and that was the signet ring upon his right hand.|He dragged it off with shaking fingers and held it up to the king.	Story of the King Who Would See Paradise	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.136: "Tell me who I am," he cried; "there is my signet, who once sat where you sit -- even yesterday!"	Story of the King Who Would See Paradise	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.137: The king looked at him compassionately, and examined the signet with curiosity.|Then he commanded, and they brought out dusty records and archives of the kingdom, and old coins of previous reigns, and compared them faithfully.|At last the king turned to the old man, and said: "Old man, such a king as this whose signet thou hast, reigned seven hundred years ago;|but he is said to have disappeared, none know whither;|where got you the ring?"	Story of the King Who Would See Paradise	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.138: Then the old man smote his breast, and cried out with a loud lamentation;|for he understood that he, who was not content to wait patiently to see the Paradise of the faithful, had been judged already.|And he turned and left the hall without a word, and went into the jungle, where he lived for twenty-five years a life of prayer and meditations, until at last the Angel of Death came to him, and mercifully released him, purged and purified through his punishment.	Story of the King Who Would See Paradise	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.139: A Pathan story told to Major Campbell.	Story of the King Who Would See Paradise	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.140: How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.141: by Andrew Lang, 1906	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.142: Far away in a hot country, where the forests are very thick and dark, and the rivers very swift and strong, there once lived a strange pair of friends.|Now one of the friends was a big white rabbit named Isuro, and the other was a tall baboon called Gudu, and so fond were they of each other that they were seldom seen apart.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.143: One day, when the sun was hotter even than usual, the rabbit awoke from his midday sleep, and saw Gudu the baboon standing beside him.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.144: "Get up," said Gudu; "I am going courting, and you must come with me.|So put some food in a bag, and sling it round your neck, for we may not be able to find anything to eat for a long while."	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.145: Then the rabbit rubbed his eyes, and gathered a store of fresh green things from under the bushes, and told Gudu that he was ready for the journey.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.146: They went on quite happily for some distance, and at last they came to a river with rocks scattered here and there across the stream.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.147: "We can never jump those wide spaces if we are burdened with food," said Gudu, "we must throw it into the river, unless we wish to fall in ourselves."|And stooping down, unseen by Isuro, who was in front of him, Gudu picked up a big stone, and threw it into the water with a loud splash.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.148: "It is your turn now," he cried to Isuro.|And with a heavy sigh, the rabbit unfastened his bag of food, which fell into the river.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.149: The road on the other side led down an avenue of trees, and before they had gone very far Gudu opened the bag that lay hidden in the thick hair about his neck, and began to eat some delicious-looking fruit.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.150: "Where did you get that from?" asked Isuro enviously.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.151: "Oh, I found after all that I could get across the rocks quite easily, so it seemed a pity not to keep my bag," answered Gudu.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.152: "Well, as you tricked me into throwing away mine, you ought to let me share with you," said Isuro.|But Gudu pretended not to hear him, and strode along the path.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.153: By-and-bye they entered a wood, and right in front of them was a tree so laden with fruit that its branches swept the ground.|And some of the fruit was still green, and some yellow.|The rabbit hopped forward with joy, for he was very hungry;|but Gudu said to him: "Pluck the green fruit, you will find it much the best.|I will leave it all for you, as you have had no dinner, and take the yellow for myself."|So the rabbit took one of the green oranges and began to bite it, but its skin was so hard that he could hardly get his teeth through the rind.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.154: "It does not taste at all nice," he cried, screwing up his face; "I would rather have one of the yellow ones."	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.155: "No! no!|I really could not allow that," answered Gudu.|"They would only make you ill.|Be content with the green fruit."|And as they were all he could get, Isuro was forced to put up with them.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.156: After this had happened two or three times, Isuro at last had his eyes opened, and made up his mind that, whatever Gudu told him, he would do exactly the opposite.|However, by this time they had reached the village where dwelt Gudu's future wife, and as they entered Gudu pointed to a clump of bushes, and said to Isuro: "Whenever I am eating, and you hear me call out that my food has burnt me, run as fast as you can and gather some of those leaves that they may heal my mouth."	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.157: The rabbit would have liked to ask him why he ate food that he knew would burn him, only he was afraid, and just nodded in reply;|but when they had gone on a little further, he said to Gudu: "I have dropped my needle;|wait here a moment while I go and fetch it."	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.158: "Be quick then," answered Gudu, climbing into a tree.|And the rabbit hastened back to the bushes, and gathered a quantity of the leaves, which he hid among his fur, "For," thought he, "if I get them now I shall save myself the trouble of a walk by-and-by."	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.159: When he had plucked as many as he wanted he returned to Gudu, and they went on together.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.160: The sun was almost setting by the time they reached their journey's end and being very tired they gladly sat down by a well.|Then Gudu's betrothed, who had been watching for him, brought out a pitcher of water -- which she poured over them to wash off the dust of the road -- and two portions of food.|But once again the rabbit's hopes were dashed to the ground, for Gudu said hastily: "The custom of the village forbids you to eat till I have finished."	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.161: And Isuro did not know that Gudu was lying, and that he only wanted more food.|So he saw hungrily looking on, waiting till his friend had had enough.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.162: In a little while Gudu screamed loudly: "I am burnt! I am burnt!" though he was not burnt at all.|Now, though Isuro had the leaves about him, he did not dare to produce them at the last moment lest the baboon should guess why he had stayed behind.|So he just went round a corner for a short time, and then came hopping back in a great hurry.|But, quick though he was, Gudu had been quicker still, and nothing remained but some drops of water.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.163: "How unlucky you are," said Gudu, snatching the leaves;|"no sooner had you gone than ever so many people arrived, and washed their hands, as you see, and ate your portion."|But, though Isuro knew better than to believe him, he said nothing, and went to bed hungrier than he had ever been in his life.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.164: Early next morning they started for another village, and passed on the way a large garden where people were very busy gathering monkey-nuts.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.165: "You can have a good breakfast at last," said Gudu, pointing to a heap of empty shells;|never doubting but that Isuro would meekly take the portion shown him, and leave the real nuts for himself.|But what was his surprise when Isuro answered: "Thank you;|I think I should prefer these."|And, turning to the kernels, never stopped as long as there was one left.|And the worst of it was that, with so many people about, Gudu could not take the nuts from him.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.166: It was night when they reached the village where dwelt the mother of Gudu's betrothed, who laid meat and millet porridge before them.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.167: "I think you told me you were fond of porridge," said Gudu;|but Isuro answered: "You are mistaking me for somebody else, as I always eat meat when I can get it."|And again Gudu was forced to be content with the porridge, which he hated.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.168: While he was eating it, however a sudden thought darted into his mind, and he managed to knock over a great pot of water which was hanging in front of the fire, and put it quite out.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.169: "Now," said the cunning creature to himself, "I shall be able in the dark to steal his meat!"|But the rabbit had grown as cunning as he, and standing in a corner hid the meat behind him, so that the baboon could not find it.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.170: "O Gudu!" he cried, laughing aloud, "it is you who have taught me to be clever."|And calling to the people of the house, he bade them kindle the fire, for Gudu would sleep by it, but that he would pass the night with some friends in another hut.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.171: It was still quite dark when Isuro heard his name called very softly, and, on opening his eyes, beheld Gudu standing by him.|Laying his finger on his nose, in token of silence, he signed to Isuro to get up and follow him, and it was not until they were some distance from the hut that Gudu spoke.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.172: "I am hungry and want something to eat better than that nasty porridge that I had for supper.|So I am going to kill one of those goats, and as you are a good cook you must boil the flesh for me."|The rabbit nodded, and Gudu disappeared behind a rock, but soon returned dragging the dead goat with him.|The two then set about skinning it, after which they stuffed the skin with dried leaves, so that no one would have guessed it was not alive, and set it up in the middle of a lump of bushes, which kept it firm on its feet.|While he was doing this, Isuro collected sticks for a fire, and when it was kindled, Gudu hastened to another hut to steal a pot which he filled with water from the river, and, planting two branches in the ground, they hung the pot with the meat in it over the fire.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.173: "It will not be fit to eat for two hours at least," said Gudu, "so we can both have a nap."|And he stretched himself out on the ground, and pretended to fall fast asleep, but, in reality, he was only waiting till it was safe to take all the meat for himself.|"Surely I hear him snore," he thought;|and he stole to the place where Isuro was lying on a pile of wood, but the rabbit's eyes were wide open.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.174: "How tiresome," muttered Gudu, as he went back to his place;|and after waiting a little longer he got up, and peeped again, but still the rabbit's pink eyes stared widely.|If Gudu had only known, Isuro was asleep all the time;|but this he never guessed, and by-and-bye he grew so tired with watching that he went to sleep himself.|Soon after, Isuro woke up, and he too felt hungry, so he crept softly to the pot and ate all the meat, while he tied the bones together and hung them in Gudu's fur.|After that he went back to the wood-pile and slept again.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.175: In the morning the mother of Gudu's betrothed came out to milk her goats, and on going to the bushes where the largest one seemed entangled, she found out the trick.|She made such lament that the people of the village came running, and Gudu and Isuro jumped up also, and pretended to be as surprised and interested as the rest.|But they must have looked guilty after all, for suddenly an old man pointed to them, and cried: "Those are thieves."|And at the sound of his voice the big Gudu trembled all over.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.176: "How dare you say such things?|I defy you to prove it," answered Isuro boldly.|And he danced forward, and turned head over heels, and shook himself before them all.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.177: "I spoke hastily; you are innocent," said the old man;|"but now let the baboon do likewise."|And when Gudu began to jump the goat's bones rattled and the people cried: "It is Gudu who is the goat-slayer!"|But Gudu answered: "Nay, I did not kill your goat;|it was Isuro, and he ate the meat, and hung the bones round my neck.|So it is he who should die!"	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.178: And the people looked at each other, for they knew not what to believe.|At length one man said: "Let them both die, but they may choose their own deaths."	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.179: Then Isuro answered: "If we must die, put us in the place where the wood is cut, and heap it up all round us, so that we cannot escape, and set fire to the wood;|and if one is burned and the other is not, then he that is burned is the goat-slayer."	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.180: And the people did as Isuro had said.|But Isuro knew of a hole under the wood-pile, and when the fire was kindled he ran into the hole, but Gudu died there.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.181: When the fire had burned itself out and only ashes were left where the wood had been, Isuro came out of his hole, and said to the people: "Lo! did I not speak well?|He who killed your goat is among those ashes."	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.182: Mashona Story.	How Isuro the Rabbit Tricked Gudu	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.183: Ian, the Soldier's Son	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.184: by Andrew Lang, 1906	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.185: There dwelt a knight in Grianaig of the land of the West, who had three daughters, and for goodness and beauty they had not their like in all the isles.|All the people loved them, and loud was the weeping when one day, as the three maidens sat on the rocks on the edge of the sea, dipping their feet in the water, there arose a great beast from under the waves and swept them away beneath the ocean.|And none knew whither they had gone, or how to seek them.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.186: Now there lived in a town a few miles off a soldier who had three sons, fine youths and strong, and the best players at shinny in that country.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.187: At Christmastide that year, when families met together and great feasts were held, Ian, the youngest of the three brothers, said: "Let us have a match at shinny on the lawn of the knight of Grianaig, for his lawn is wider and the grass smoother than ours."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.188: But the others answered: "Nay, for he is in sorrow, and he will think of the games that we have played there when his daughters looked on."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.189: "Let him be pleased or angry as he will," said Ian; "we will drive our ball on his lawn to-day."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.190: And so it was done, and Ian won three games from his brothers.|But the knight looked out of his window, and was wroth;|and bade his men bring the youths before him.|When he stood in his hall and beheld them, his heart was softened somewhat;|but his face was angry as he asked:	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.191: "Why did you choose to play shinny in front of my castle when you knew full well that the remembrance of my daughters would come back to me?|The pain which you have made me suffer you shall suffer also."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.192: "Since we have done you wrong," answered Ian, the youngest, "build us a ship, and we will go and seek your daughters.|Let them be to windward, or to leeward, or under the four brown boundaries of the sea, we will find them before a year and a day goes by, and will carry them back to Grianaig."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.193: In seven days the ship was built, and great store of food and wine placed in her.|And the three brothers put her head to the sea and sailed away, and in seven days the ship ran herself on to a beach of white sand, and they all went ashore.|They had none of them ever seen that land before, and looked about them.|Then they saw that, a short way from them, a number of men were working on a rock, with one man standing over them.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.194: "What place is this?" asked the eldest brother.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.195: And the man who was standing by made answer: "This is the place where dwell the three daughters of the knight of Grianaig, who are to be wedded to-morrow to three giants."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.196: "How can we find them?" asked the young man again.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.197: And the overlooker answered: "To reach the daughters of the knight of Grianaig you must get into this basket, and be drawn by a rope up the face of this rock."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.198: "Oh, that is easily done," said the eldest brother, jumping into the basket, which at once began to move -- up, and up, and up -- till he had gone about half-way, when a fat black raven flew at him and pecked him till he was nearly blind, so that he was forced to go back the way he had come.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.199: After that the second brother got into the creel;|but he fared no better, for the raven flew upon him, and he returned as his brother had done.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.200: "Now it is my turn," said Ian.|But when he was halfway up the raven set upon him also.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.201: "Quick! quick!" cried Ian to the men who held the rope.|"Quick! quick! or I shall be blinded!"|And the men pulled with all their might, and in another moment Ian was on top, and the raven behind him.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.202: "Will you give me a piece of tobacco?" asked the raven, who was now quite quiet.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.203: "You rascal!|Am I to give you tobacco for trying to peck my eyes out?" answered Ian.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.204: "That was part of my duty," replied the raven;|"but give it to me, and I will prove a good friend to you."|So Ian broke off a piece of tobacco and gave it to him.|The raven hid it under his wing, and then went on;|"Now I will take you to the house of the big giant, where the knight's daughter sits sewing, sewing, till even her thimble is wet with tears."|And the raven hopped before him till they reached a large house, the door of which stood open.|They entered and passed through one hall after the other, until they found the knight's daughter, as the bird had said.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.205: "What brought you here?" asked she.|And Ian made answer: "Why may I not go where you can go?"	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.206: "I was brought hither by a giant," replied she.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.207: "I know that," said Ian;|"but tell me where the giant is, that I may find him."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.208: "He is on the hunting hill," answered she;|"and nought will bring him home save a shake of the iron chain which hangs outside the gate.|But, there, neither to leeward, nor to windward, nor in the four brown boundaries of the sea, is there any man that can hold battle against him, save only Ian, the soldier's son, and he is now but sixteen years old, and how shall he stand against the giant?"	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.209: "In the land whence I have come there are many men with the strength of Ian," answered he.|And he went outside and pulled at the chain, but he could not move it, and fell on to his knees.|At that he rose swiftly, and gathering up his strength, he seized the chain, and this time he shook it so that the link broke.|And the giant heard it on the hunting hill, and lifted his head, thinking -- 	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.210: "It sounds like the noise of Ian, the soldier's son," said he;|"but as yet he is only sixteen years old.|Still, I had better look to it."|And home he came.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.211: "Are you Ian, the soldier's son?" he asked, as he entered the castle.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.212: "No, of a surety," answered the youth, who had no wish that they should know him.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.213: "Then who are you in the leeward, or in the windward, or in the four brown boundaries of the sea, who are able to move my battle-chain?"	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.214: "That will be plain to you after wrestling with me as I wrestle with my mother.|And one time she got the better of me, and two times she did not."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.215: So they wrestled, and twisted and strove with each other till the giant forced Ian to his knee.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.216: "You are the stronger," said Ian;|and the giant answered: "All men know that!"|And they took hold of each other once more, and at last Ian threw the giant, and wished that the raven were there to help him.|No sooner had he wished his wish than the raven came.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.217: "Put your hand under my right wing and you will find a knife sharp enough to take off his head," said the raven.|And the knife was so sharp that it cut off the giant's head with a blow.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.218: "Now go and tell the daughter of the king of Grianaig;|but take heed lest you listen to her words, and promise to go no further, for she will seek to help you.|Instead, seek the middle daughter, and when you have found her, you shall give me a piece of tobacco for reward."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.219: "Well have you earned the half of all I have," answered Ian.|But the raven shook his head.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.220: "You know only what has passed, and nothing of what lies before.|If you would not fail, wash yourself in clean water, and take balsam from a vessel on top of the door, and rub it over your body, and to-morrow you will be as strong as many men, and I will lead you to the dwelling of the middle one."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.221: Ian did as the raven bade him, and in spite of the eldest daughter's entreaties, he set out to seek her next sister.|He found her where she was seated sewing, her very thimble wet from the tears which she had shed.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.222: "What brought you here?" asked the second sister.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.223: "Why may I not go where you can go?" answered he;|"and why are you weeping?"	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.224: "Because in one day I shall be married to the giant who is on the hunting hill."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.225: "How can I get him home?" asked Ian.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.226: "Nought will bring him but a shake of that iron chain which hangs outside the gate.|But there is neither to leeward, nor to westward, nor in the four brown boundaries of the sea, any man that can hold battle with him, save Ian, the soldier's son, and he is now but sixteen years of age."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.227: "In the land whence I have come there are many men with the strength of Ian," said he.|And he went outside and pulled at the chain, but he could not move it, and fell on his knees.|At that he rose to his feet, and gathering up his strength mightily, he seized the chain, and this time he shook it so that three links broke.|And the second giant heard it on the hunting hill, and lifted his head, thinking -- 	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.228: "It sounds like the noise of Ian, the soldier's son," said he;|"but as yet he is only sixteen years old.|Still, I had better look to it."|And home he came.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.229: "Are you Ian, the soldier's son?" he asked, as he entered the castle.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.230: "No, of a surety," answered the youth, who had no wish that this giant should know him either;|"but I will wrestle with you as if I were he."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.231: Then they seized each other by the shoulder, and the giant threw him on his two knees.|"You are the stronger," cried Ian; "but I am not beaten yet."|And rising to his feet, he threw his arms round the giant.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.232: Backwards and forwards they swayed, and first one was uppermost and then the other;|but at length Ian worked his leg round the giant's and threw him to the ground.|Then he called to the raven, and the raven came flapping towards him, and said: "Put your hand under my right wing, and you will find there a knife sharp enough to take off his head."|And sharp indeed it was, for with a single blow, the giant's head rolled from his body.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.233: "Now wash yourself with warm water, and rub yourself over with oil of balsam, and to-morrow you will be as strong as many men.|But beware of the words of the knight's daughter, for she is cunning, and will try to keep you at her side.|So farewell;|but first give me a piece of tobacco."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.234: "That I will gladly," answered Ian breaking off a large bit.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.235: He washed and rubbed himself that night, as the raven had told him, and the next morning he entered the chamber where the knight's daughter was sitting.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.236: "Abide here with me," she said, "and be my husband.|There is silver and gold in plenty in the castle."|But he took no heed, and went on his way till he reached the castle where the knight's youngest daughter was sewing in the hall.|And tears dropped from her eyes on to her thimble.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.237: "What brought you here?" asked she.|And Ian made answer: "Why may I not go where you can go?"	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.238: "I was brought hither by a giant."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.239: "I know full well," said he.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.240: "Are you Ian, the soldier's son?" asked she again.|And again he answered: "Yes, I am;|but tell me, why are you weeping?"	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.241: "To-morrow the giant will return from the hunting hill, and I must marry him," she sobbed.|And Ian took no heed, and only said: "How can I bring him home?"	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.242: "Shake the iron chain that hangs outside the gate."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.243: And Ian went out, and gave such a pull to the chain that he fell down at full length from the force of the shake.|But in a moment he was on his feet again, and seized the chain with so much strength that four links came off in his hand.|And the giant heard him in the hunting hill, as he was putting the game he had killed into a bag.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.244: "In the leeward, or the windward, or in the four brown boundaries of the sea, there is none who could give my chain a shake save only Ian, the soldier's son.|And if he has reached me, then he has left my two brothers dead behind him."|With that he strode back to the castle, the earth trembling under him as he went.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.245: "Are you Ian, the soldier's son?" asked he.|And the youth answered:	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.246: "No, of a surety."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.247: "Then who are you in the leeward, or the windward, or in the four brown boundaries of the sea, who are able to shake my battle chain?|There is only Ian, the soldier's son, who can do this, and he is but now sixteen years old.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.248: "I will show you who I am when you have wrestled with me," said Ian.|And they threw their arms round each other, and the giant forced Ian on to his knees;|but in a moment he was up again, and crooking his leg round the shoulders of the giant, he threw him heavily to the ground.|"Stumpy black raven, come quick!" cried he;|and the raven came, and beat the giant about the head with his wings, so that he could not get up.|Then he bade Ian take out a sharp knife from under his feathers, which he carried with him for cutting berries, and Ian smote off the giant's head with it.|And so sharp was that knife that, with one blow, the giant's head rolled on the ground.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.249: "Rest now this night also," said the raven, "and to-morrow you shall take the knight's three daughters to the edge of the rock that leads to the lower world.|But take heed to go down first yourself, and let them follow after you.|And before I go you shall give me a piece of tobacco."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.250: "Take it all," answered Ian, "for well have you earned it."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.251: "No;|give me but a piece.|You know what is behind you, but you have no knowledge of what is before you."|And picking up the tobacco in his beak, the raven flew away.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.252: So the next morning the knight's youngest daughter loaded asses with all the silver and gold to be found in the castle, and she set out with Ian the soldier's son for the house where her second sister was waiting to see what would befall.|She also had asses laden with precious things to carry away, and so had the eldest sister, when they reached the castle where she had been kept a prisoner.|Together they all rode to the edge of the rock, and then Ian lay down and shouted, and the basket was drawn up, and in it they got one by one, and were let down to the bottom.|When the last one was gone, Ian should have gone also, and left the three sisters to come after him;|but he had forgotten the raven's warning, and bade them go first, lest some accident should happen.|Only, he begged the youngest sister to let him keep the little gold cap which, like the others, she wore on her head;|and then he helped them, each in her turn, into the basket.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.253: Long he waited, but wait as he might, the basket never came back, for in their joy at being free the knight's daughters had forgotten all about Ian, and had set sail in the ship that had brought him and his brothers to the land of Grianaig.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.254: At last he began to understand what had happened to him, and while he was taking counsel with himself what had best be done, the raven came to him.|"You did not heed my words," he said gravely.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.255: "No, I did not, and therefore am I here," answered Ian, bowing his head.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.256: "The past cannot be undone," went on the raven.|"He that will not take counsel will take combat.|This night, you will sleep in the giant's castle.|And now you shall give me a piece of tobacco."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.257: "I will.|But, I pray you, stay in the castle with me."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.258: "That I may not do, but on the morrow I will come."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.259: And on the morrow he did, and he bade Ian go to the giant's stable where stood a horse to whom it mattered nothing if she journeyed over land or sea.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.260: "But be careful," he added, "how you enter the stable, for the door swings without ceasing to and fro, and if it touches you, it will cause you to cry out.|I will go first and show you the way."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.261: "Go," said Ian.|And the raven gave a bob and a hop, and thought he was quite safe, but the door slammed on a feather of his tail, and he screamed loudly.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.262: Then Ian took a run backwards, and a run forwards, and made a spring;|but the door caught one of his feet, and he fell fainting on the stable floor.|Quickly the raven pounced on him, and picked him up in his beak and claws, and carried him back to the castle, where he laid ointments on his foot till it was as well as ever it was.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.263: "Now come out to walk," said the raven, "but take heed that you wonder not at aught you may behold;|neither shall you touch anything.|And, first, give me a piece of tobacco."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.264: Many strange things did Ian behold in that island, more than he had thought for.|In a glen lay three heroes stretched on their backs, done to death by three spears that still stuck in their breasts.|But he kept his counsel and spake nothing, only he pulled out the spears, and the men sat up and said: "You are Ian the soldier's son, and a spell is laid upon you to travel in our company, to the cave of the black fisherman."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.265: So together they went till they reached the cave, and one of the men entered, to see what should be found there.|And he beheld a hag, horrible to look upon, seated on a rock, and before he could speak, she struck him with her club, and changed him into a stone;|and in like manner she dealt with the other three.|At the last Ian entered.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.266: "These men are under spells," said the witch, "and alive they can never be till you have anointed them with the water which you must fetch from the island of Big Women.|See that you do not tarry."|And Ian turned away with a sinking heart, for he would fain have followed the youngest daughter of the knight of Grianaig.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.267: "You did not obey my counsel," said the raven, hopping towards him, "and so trouble has come upon you.|But sleep now, and to-morrow you shall mount the horse which is in the giant's stable, that can gallop over sea and land.|When you reach the island of Big Women, sixteen boys will come to meet you, and will offer the horse food, and wish to take her saddle and bridle from her.|But see that they touch her not, and give her food yourself, and yourself lead her into the stable, and shut the door.|And be sure that for every turn of the lock given by the sixteen stable lads you give one.|And now you shall break me off a piece of tobacco."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.268: The next morning Ian arose, and led the horse from the stable, without the door hurting him, and he rode across the sea to the island of the Big Women, where the sixteen stable lads met him, and each one offered to take his horse, and to feed her, and to put her into the stable.|But Ian only answered:	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.269: "I myself will put her in and will see to her."|And thus he did.|And while he was rubbing her sides the horse said to him: "Every kind of drink will they offer you, but see you take none, save whey and water only."|And so it fell out;|and when the sixteen stable-boys saw that he would drink nothing, they drank it all themselves, and one by one lay stretched around the board.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.270: Then Ian felt pleased in his heart that he had withstood their fair words, and he forgot the counsel that the horse had likewise given him saying: "Beware lest you fall asleep, and let slip the chance of getting home again';|for while the lads were sleeping sweet music reached his ears, and he slept also.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.271: When this came to pass the steed broke through the stable door, and kicked him and woke him roughly.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.272: "You did not heed my counsel," said she;|"and who knows if it is not too late to win over the sea?|But first take that sword which hangs on the wall, and cut off the heads of the sixteen grooms."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.273: Filled with shame at being once more proved heedless, Ian arose and did as the horse bade him.|Then he ran to the well and poured some of the water into a leather bottle, and jumping on the horse's back rode over the sea to the island where the raven was waiting for him.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.274: "Lead the horse into the stable," said the raven, "and lie down yourself to sleep, for to-morrow you must make the heroes to live again, and must slay the hag.|And have a care not to be so foolish to-morrow as you were to-day."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.275: "Stay with me for company," begged Ian;|but the raven shook his head, and flew away.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.276: In the morning Ian awoke, and hastened to the cave where the old hag was sitting, and he struck her dead as she was, before she could cast spells on him.|Next he sprinkled the water over the heroes, who came to life again, and together they all journeyed to the other side of the island, and there the raven met them.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.277: "At last you have followed the counsel that was given you," said the raven;|"and now, having learned wisdom, you may go home again to Grianaig.|There you will find that the knight's two eldest daughters are to be wedded this day to your two brothers, and the youngest to the chief of the men at the rock.|But her gold cap you shall give to me and, if you want it, you have only to think of me and I will bring it to you.|And one more warning I give you.|If anyone asks you whence you came, answer that you have come from behind you;|and if anyone asks you whither you are going, say that you are going before you."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.278: So Ian mounted the horse and set her face to the sea and her back to the shore, and she was off, away and away till she reached the church of Grianaig, and there, in a field of grass, beside a well of water, he leaped down from his saddle.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.279: "Now," the horse said to him, "draw your sword and cut off my head."|But Ian answered: "Poor thanks would that be for all the help I have had from you."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.280: "It is the only way that I can free myself from the spells that were laid by the giants on me and the raven; for I was a girl and he was a youth wooing me!|So have no fears, but do as I have said."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.281: Then Ian drew his sword as she bade him, and cut off her head, and went on his way without looking backwards.|As he walked he saw a woman standing at her house door.|She asked him whence he had come, and he answered as the raven had told him, that he came from behind.|Next she inquired whither he was going, and this time he made reply that he was going on before him, but that he was thirsty and would like a drink.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.282: "You are an impudent fellow," said the woman;|"but you shall have a drink."|And she gave him some milk, which was all she had till her husband came home.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.283: "Where is your husband?" asked Ian, and the woman answered him: "He is at the knight's castle trying to fashion gold and silver into a cap for the youngest daughter, like unto the caps that her sisters wear, such as are not to be found in all this land.|But, see, he is returning;|and now we shall hear how he has sped."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.284: At that the man entered the gate, and beholding a strange youth, he said to him: "What is your trade, boy?"	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.285: "I am a smith," replied Ian.|And the man answered: "Good luck has befallen me, then, for you can help me to make a cap for the knight's daughter."	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.286: "You cannot make that cap, and you know it," said Ian.	Ian, the Soldier's Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
