content.774: The years passed on, and by-and-by another council was held, and it was agreed that the king's sons were now of an age to take the power which rightly belonged to them.|So the youths were bidden to appear before the council, and Oireal the elder was smaller and weaker than his brother.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.775: "I like not to leave the deer on the hill and the fish in the rivers, and sit in judgment on my people," said Oireal, when he had listened to the words of the chief of the council.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.776: And the chief waxed angry, and answered quickly: "Not one clod of earth shall ever be yours if this day you do not take on yourself the vows that were taken by the king your father."	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.777: Then spake Iarlaid, the younger, and he said: "Let one half be yours, and the other give to me;|then you will have fewer people to rule over."	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.778: "Yes, I will do that," answered Oireal.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.779: After this, one half of the men of the land of Lochlann did homage to Oireal, and the other half to Iarlaid.|And they governed their kingdoms as they would, and in a few years they became grown men with beards on their chins;|and Iarlaid married the daughter of the king of Greece, and Oireal the daughter of the king of Orkney.|The next year sons were born to Oireal and Iarlaid;|and the son of Oireal was big and strong, but the son of Iarlaid was little and weak, and each had six foster brothers who went everywhere with the princes.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.780: One day Manus, son of Oireal, and his cousin, the son of Iarlaid, called to their foster brothers, and bade them come and play a game at shinny in the great field near the school where they were taught all that princes and nobles should know.|Long they played, and swiftly did the ball pass from one to another, when Manus drove the ball at his cousin, the son of Iarlaid.|The boy, who was not used to be roughly handled, even in jest, cried out that he was sorely hurt, and went home with his foster brothers and told his tale to his mother.|The wife of Iarlaid grew white and angry as she listened, and thrusting her son aside, sought the council hall where Iarlaid was sitting.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.781: "Manus has driven a ball at my son, and fain would have slain him," said she.|"Let an end be put to him and his ill deeds."	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.782: But Iarlaid answered: "Nay, I will not slay the son of my brother."	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.783: "And he shall not slay my son," said the queen.|And calling to her chamberlain she ordered him to lead the prince to the four brown boundaries of the world, and to leave him there with a wise man, who would care for him, and let no harm befall him.|And the wise man set the boy on the top of a hill where the sun always shone, and he could see every man, but no man could see him.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.784: Then she summoned Manus to the castle, and for a whole year she kept him fast, and his own mother could not get speech of him.|But in the end, when the wife of Oireal fell sick, Manus fled from the tower which was his prison, and stole back to his on home.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.785: For a few years he stayed there in peace, and then the wife of Iarlaid his uncle sent for him.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.786: "It is time that you were married," she said, when she saw that Manus had grown tall and strong like unto Iarlaid.|"Tall and strong you are, and comely of face.|I know a bride that will suit you well, and that is the daughter of the mighty earl of Finghaidh, that does homage for his lands to me.|I myself will go with a great following to his house, and you shall go with me."	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.787: Thus it was done;|and though the earl's wife was eager to keep her daughter with her yet a while, she was fain to yield, as the wife of Iarlaid vowed that not a rood of land should the earl have, unless he did her bidding.|But if he would give his daughter to Manus, she would bestow on him the third part of her own kingdom, with much treasure beside.|This she did, not from love to Manus, but because she wished to destroy him.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.788: So they were married, and rode back with the wife of Iarlaid to her own palace.|And that night, while he was sleeping, there came a wise man, who was his father's friend, and awoke him saying: "Danger lies very close to you, Manus, son of Oireal.|You hold yourself favoured because you have as a bride the daughter of a mighty earl;|but do you know what bride the wife of Iarlaid sought for her own son?|It was no worldly wife she found for him, but the swift March wind, and never can you prevail against her."	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.789: "Is it thus?" answered Manu.|And at the first streak of dawn he went to the chamber where the queen lay in the midst of her maidens.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.790: "I have come," he said, "for the third part of the kingdom, and for the treasure which you promised me."|But the wife of Iarlaid laughed as she heard him.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.791: "Not a clod shall you have here," spake she.|"You must go to the Old Bergen for that.|Mayhap under its stones and rough mountains you may find a treasure!"	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.792: "Then give me your son's six foster brothers as well as my own," answered he.|And the queen gave them to him, and they set out for Old Bergen.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.793: A year passed by, and found them still in that wild land, hunting the reindeer, and digging pits for the mountain sheep to fall into.|For a time Manus and his companions lived merrily, but at length Manus grew weary of the strange country, and they all took ship for the land of Lochlann.|The wind was fierce and cold, and long was the voyage;|but, one spring day, they sailed into the harbour that lay beneath the castle of Iarlaid.|The queen looked from her window and beheld him mounting the hill, with the twelve foster brothers behind him.|Then she said to her husband: "Manus has returned with his twelve foster brothers.|Would that I could put an end to him and his murdering and his slaying."	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.794: "That were a great pity," answered Iarlaid.|"And it is not I that will do it."	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.795: "If you will not do it I will," said she.|And she called the twelve foster brothers and made them vow fealty to herself.|So Manus was left with no man, and sorrowful was he when he returned alone to Old Bergen.|It was late when his foot touched the shore, and took the path towards the forest.|On his way there met him a man in a red tunic.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.796: "Is it you, Manus, come back again?" asked he.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.797: "It is I," answered Manus; "alone have I returned from the land of Lochlann."	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.798: The man eyed him silently for a moment, and then he said: "I dreamed that you were girt with a sword and became king of Lochlann."	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.799: But Manus answered: "I have no sword and my bow is broken."	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.800: "I will give you a new sword if you will make me a promise," said the man once more.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.801: "To be sure I will make it, if ever I am king," answered Manus.|"But speak, and tell me what promise I am to make."	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.802: "I was your grandfather's armourer," replied the man, "and I wish to be your armourer also."	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.803: "That I will promise readily," said Manus;|and followed the man into his house, which was at a little distance.|But the house was not like other houses, for the walls of every room were hung so thick with arms that you could not see the boards.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.804: "Choose what you will," said the man;|and Manus unhooked a sword and tried it across his knee, and it broke, and so did the next, and the next.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.805: "Leave off breaking the swords," cried the man, "and look at this old sword and helmet and tunic that I wore in the wars of your grandfather.|Perhaps you may find them of stouter steel."|And Manus bent the sword thrice across his knee but he could not break it.|So he girded it to his side, and put on the old helmet.|As he fastened the strap his eye fell on a cloth flapping outside the window.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.806: "What cloth is that?" asked he.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.807: "It is a cloth that was woven by the Little People of the forest," said the man;|"and when you are hungry it will give you food and drink, and if you meet a foe, he will not hurt you, but will stoop and kiss the back of your hand in token of submission.|Take it, and use it well."|Manus gladly wrapped the shawl round his arm, and was leaving the house, when he heard the rattling of a chain blown by the wind.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.808: "What chain is that?" asked he.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.809: "The creature who has that chain round his neck, need not fear a hundred enemies," answered the armourer.|And Manus wound it round him and passed on into the forest.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.810: Suddenly there sprang out from the bushes two lions, and a lion cub with them.|The fierce beasts bounded towards him, roaring loudly, and would fain have eaten him, but quickly Manus stooped and spread the cloth upon the ground.|At that the lions stopped, and bowing their great heads, kissed the back of his wrist and went their ways.|But the cub rolled itself up in the cloth;|so Manus picked them both up, and carried them with him to Old Bergen.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.811: Another year went by, and then he took the lion cub and set forth to the land of Lochlann.|And the wife of Iarlaid came to meet him, and a brown dog, small but full of courage, came with her.|When the dog beheld the lion cub he rushed towards him, thinking to eat him;|but the cub caught the dog by the neck, and shook him, and he was dead.|And the wife of Iarlaid mourned him sore, and her wrath was kindled, and many times she tried to slay Manus and his cub, but she could not.|And at last they two went back to Old Bergen, and the twelve foster brothers went also.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.812: "Let them go," said the wife of Iarlaid, when she heard of it.|"My brother the Red Gruagach will take the head off Manus as well in Old Bergen as elsewhere."	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.813: Now these words were carried by a messenger to the wife of Oireal, and she made haste and sent a ship to Old Bergen to bear away her son before the Red Gruagach should take the head off him.|And in the ship was a pilot.|But the wife of Iarlaid made a thick fog to cover the face of the sea, and the rowers could not row, lest they should drive the ship on to a rock.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.814: And when night came, the lion cub, whose eyes were bright and keen, stole up to Manus, and Manus got on his back, and the lion cub sprang ashore and bade Manus rest on the rock and wait for him.|So Manus slept, and by-and-by a voice sounded in his ears, saying: "Arise!"|And he saw a ship in the water beneath him, and in the ship sat the lion cup in the shape of the pilot.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.815: Then they sailed away through the fog, and none saw them;|and they reached the land of Lochlann, and the lion cub with the chain round his neck sprang from the ship and Manus followed after.|And the lion cub killed all the men that guarded the castle, and Iarlaid and his wife also, so that, in the end, Manus son of Oireal was crowned king of Lochlann.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.816: Shortened from West Highland Tales.	The Story of Manus	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.817: Pinkel the Thief	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.818: by Andrew Lang, 1906	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.819: Long, long ago there lived a widow who had three sons.|The two eldest were grown up, and though they were known to be idle fellows, some of the neighbours had given them work to do on account of the respect in which their mother was held.|But at the time this story begins they had both been so careless and idle that their masters declared they would keep them no longer.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.820: So home they went to their mother and youngest brother, of whom they thought little, because he made himself useful about the house, and looked after the hens, and milked the cow.|"Pinkel," they called him in scorn, and by-and-by "Pinkel" became his name throughout the village.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.821: The two young men thought it was much nicer to live at home and be idle than to be obliged to do a quantity of disagreeable things they did not like, and they would have stayed by the fire till the end of their lives had not the widow lost patience with them and said that since they would not look for work at home they must seek it elsewhere, for she would not have them under her roof any longer.|But she repented bitterly of her words when Pinkel told her that he too was old enough to go out into the world, and that when he had made a fortune he would send for his mother to keep house for him.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.822: The widow wept many tears at parting from her youngest son, but as she saw that his heart was set upon going with his brothers, she did not try to keep him.|So the young men started off one morning in high spirits, never doubting that work such as they might be willing to do would be had for the asking, as soon as their little store of money was spent.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.823: But a very few days of wandering opened their eyes.|Nobody seemed to want them, or, if they did, the young men declared that they were not able to undertake all that the farmers or millers or woodcutters required of them.|The youngest brother, who was wiser, would gladly have done some of the work that the others refused, but he was small and slight, and no one thought of offering him any.|Therefore they went from one place to another, living only on the fruit and nuts they could find in the woods, and getting hungrier every day.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.824: One night, after they had been walking for many hours and were very tired, they came to a large lake with an island in the middle of it.|From the island streamed a strong light, by which they could see everything almost as clearly as if the sun had been shining, and they perceived that, lying half hidden in the rushes, was a boat.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.825: "Let us take it and row over to the island, where there must be a house," said the eldest brother;|"and perhaps they will give us food and shelter."|And they all got in and rowed across in the direction of the light.|As they drew near the island they saw that it came from a golden lantern hanging over the door of a hut, while sweet tinkling music proceeded from some bells attached to the golden horns of a goat which was feeding near the cottage.|The young men's hearts rejoiced as they thought that at last they would be able to rest their weary limbs, and they entered the hut, but were amazed to see an ugly old woman inside, wrapped in a cloak of gold which lighted up the whole house.|They looked at each other uneasily as she came forward with her daughter, as they knew by the cloak that this was a famous witch.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.826: "What do you want?" asked she, at the same time signing to her daughter to stir the large pot on the fire.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.827: "We are tired and hungry, and would fain have shelter for the night," answered the eldest brother.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.828: "You cannot get it here," said the witch, "but you will find both food and shelter in the palace on the other side of the lake.|Take your boat and go;|but leave this boy with me -- I can find work for him, though something tells me he is quick and cunning, and will do me ill."	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.829: "What harm can a poor boy like me do a great Troll like you?" answered Pinkel.|"Let me go, I pray you, with my brothers.|I will promise never to hurt you."|And at last the witch let him go, and he followed his brothers to the boat.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.830: The way was further than they thought, and it was morning before they reached the palace.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.831: Now, at last, their luck seemed to have turned, for while the two eldest were given places in the king's stables, Pinkel was taken as page to the little prince.|He was a clever and amusing boy, who saw everything that passed under his eyes, and the king noticed this, and often employed him in his own service, which made his brothers very jealous.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.832: Things went on this way for some time, and Pinkel every day rose in the royal favour.|At length the envy of his brothers became so great that they could bear it no longer, and consulted together how best they might ruin his credit with the king.|They did not wish to kill him -- though, perhaps, they would not have been sorry if they had heard he was dead -- but merely wished to remind him that he was after all only a child, not half so old and wise as they.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.833: Their opportunity soon came.|It happened to be the king's custom to visit his stables once a week, so that he might see that his horses were being properly cared for.|The next time he entered the stables the two brothers managed to be in the way, and when the king praised the beautiful satin skins of the horses under their charge, and remarked how different was their condition when his grooms had first come across the lake, the young men at once began to speak of the wonderful light which sprang from the lantern over the hut.|The king, who had a passion for collection all the rarest things he could find, fell into the trap directly, and inquired where he could get this marvellous lantern.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.834: "Send Pinkel for it, Sire," said they.|"It belongs to an old witch, who no doubt came by it in some evil way.|But Pinkel has a smooth tongue, and he can get the better of any woman, old or young."	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.835: "Then bid him go this very night," cried the king;|"and if he brings me the lantern I will make him one of the chief men about my person."	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.836: Pinkel was much pleased at the thought of his adventure, and without more ado he borrowed a little boat which lay moored to the shore, and rowed over to the island at once.|It was late by the time he arrived, and almost dark, but he knew by the savoury smell that reached him that the witch was cooking her supper.|So he climbed softly on to the roof, and, peering, watched till the old woman's back was turned, when he quickly drew a handful of salt from his pocket and threw it into the pot.|Scarcely had he done this when the witch called her daughter and bade her lift the pot off the fire and put the stew into a dish, as it had been cooking quite long enough and she was hungry.|But no sooner had she tasted it than she put her spoon down, and declared that her daughter must have been meddling with it, for it was impossible to eat anything that was all made of salt.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.837: "Go down to the spring in the valley, and get some fresh water, that I may prepare a fresh supper," cried she, "for I feel half-starved."	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.838: "But, mother," answered the girl, "how can I find the well in this darkness?|For you know that the lantern's rays shed no light down there."	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.839: "Well, then, take the lantern with you," answered the witch, "for supper I must have, and there is no water that is nearer."	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.840: So the girl took her pail in one hand and the golden lantern in the other, and hastened away to the well, followed by Pinkel, who took care to keep out of the way of the rays.|When at last she stooped to fill her pail at the well Pinkel pushed her into it, and snatching up the lantern hurried back to his boat and rowed off from the shore.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.841: He was already a long distance from the island when the witch, who wondered what had become of her daughter, went to the door to look for her.|Close around the hut was thick darkness, but what was that bobbing light that streamed across the water?|The witch's heart sank as all at once it flashed upon her what had happened.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.842: "Is that you, Pinkel?" cried she;|and the youth answered:	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.843: "Yes, dear mother, it is I!"	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.844: "And are you not a knave for robbing me?" said she.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.845: "Truly, dear mother, I am," replied Pinkel, rowing faster than ever, for he was half afraid that the witch might come after him.|But she had no power on the water, and turned angrily into the hut, muttering to herself all the while: "Take care! take care!|A second time you will not escape so easily!"	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.846: The sun had not yet risen when Pinkel returned to the palace, and, entering the king's chamber, he held up the lantern so that its rays might fall upon the bed.|In an instant the king awoke, and seeing the golden lantern shedding its light upon him, he sprang up, and embraced Pinkel with joy.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.847: "O cunning one," cried he, "what treasure hast thou brought me!"|And calling for his attendants he ordered that rooms next his own should be prepared for Pinkel, and that the youth might enter his presence at any hour.|And besides this, he was to have a seat on the council.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.848: It may easily be guessed that all this made the brothers more envious than they were before;|and they cast about in their minds afresh how best they might destroy him.|At length they remembered the goat with golden horns and the bells, and they rejoiced;|"For," said they, "THIS time the old woman will be on the watch, and let him be as clever as he likes, the bells on the horns are sure to warn her."|So when, as before, the king came down to the stables and praised the cleverness of their brother, the young men told him of that other marvel possessed by the witch, the goat with the golden horns.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.849: From this moment the king never closed his eyes at night for longing after this wonderful creature.|He understood something of the danger that there might be in trying to steal it, now that the witch's suspicions were aroused, and he spent hours in making plans for outwitting her.|But somehow he never could think of anything that would do, and at last, as the brothers had foreseen, he sent for Pinkel.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.850: "I hear," he said, "that the old witch on the island has a goat with golden horns from which hang bells that tinkle the sweetest music.|That goat I must have!|But, tell me, how am I to get it?|I would give the third part of my kingdom to anyone who would bring it to me."	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.851: "I will fetch it myself," answered Pinkel.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.852: This time it was easier for Pinkel to approach the island unseen, as there was no golden lantern to thrown its beams over the water.|But, on the other hand, the goat slept inside the hut, and would therefore have to be taken from under the very eyes of the old woman.|How was he to do it?|All the way across the lake he thought and thought, till at length a plan came into his head which seemed as if it might do, though he knew it would be very difficult to carry out.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.853: The first thing he did when he reached the shore was to look about for a piece of wood, and when he had found it he hid himself close to the hut, till it grew quite dark and near the hour when the witch and her daughter went to bed.|Then he crept up and fixed the wood under the door, which opened outwards, in such a manner that the more you tried to shut it the more firmly it stuck.|And this was what happened when the girl went as usual to bolt the door and make all fast for the night.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.854: "What are you doing?" asked the witch, as her daughter kept tugging at the handle.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.855: "There is something the matter with the door;|it won't shut," answered she.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.856: "Well, leave it alone;|there is nobody to hurt us," said the witch, who was very sleepy;|and the girl did as she was bid, and went to bed.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.857: Very soon they both might have been heard snoring, and Pinkel knew that his time was come.|Slipping off his shoes he stole into the hut on tiptoe, and taking from his pocket some food of which the goat was particularly fond, he laid it under his nose.|Then, while the animal was eating it, he stuffed each golden bell with wool which he had also brought with him, stopping every minute to listen, lest the witch should awaken, and he should find himself changed into some dreadful bird or beast.|But the snoring still continued, and he went on with his work as quickly as he could.|When the last bell was done he drew another handful of food out of his pocket, and held it out to the goat, which instantly rose to its feet and followed Pinkel, who backed slowly to the door, and directly he got outside he seized the goat in his arms and ran down to the place where he had moored his boat.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.858: As soon as he had reached the middle of the lake, Pinkel took the wool out of the bells, which began to tinkle loudly.|Their sound awoke the witch, who cried out as before: "Is that you, Pinkel?"	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.859: "Yes, dear mother, it is I," said Pinkel.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.860: "Have you stolen my golden goat?" asked she.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.861: "Yes, dear mother, I have," answered Pinkel.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.862: "Are you not a knave, Pinkel?"	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.863: "Yes, dear mother, I am," he replied.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.864: And the old witch shouted in a rage: "Ah! beware how you come hither again, for next time you shall not escape me!"	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.865: But Pinkel laughed and rowed on.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.866: The king was so delighted with the goat that he always kept it by his side, night and day;|and, as he had promised, Pinkel was made ruler over the third part of the kingdom.|As may be supposed, the brothers were more furious than ever, and grew quite thin with rage.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.867: "How can we get rid of him?" said one to the other.|And at length they remembered the golden cloak.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.868: "He will need to be clever if he is to steal that!" they cried, with a chuckle.|And when next the king came to see his horses they began to speak of Pinkel and his marvellous cunning, and how he had contrived to steal the lantern and the goat, which nobody else would have been able to do.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.869: "But as he was there, it is a pity he could not have brought away the golden cloak," added they.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.870: "The golden cloak!|what is that?" asked the king.|And the young men described its beauties in such glowing words that the king declared he should never know a day's happiness till he had wrapped the cloak round his own shoulders.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.871: "And," added he, "the man who brings it to me shall wed my daughter, and shall inherit my throne."	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.872: "None can get it save Pinkel," said they;|for they did not imagine that the witch, after two warnings, could allow their brother to escape a third time.|So Pinkel was sent for, and with a glad heart he set out.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.873: He passed many hours inventing first one plan and then another, till he had a scheme ready which he thought might prove successful.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.874: Thrusting a large bag inside his coat, he pushed off from the shore, taking care this time to reach the island in daylight.|Having made his boat fast to a tree, he walked up to the hut, hanging his head, and putting on a face that was both sorrowful and ashamed.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.875: "Is that you, Pinkel?" asked the witch when she saw him, her eyes gleaming savagely.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.876: "Yes, dear mother, it is I," answered Pinkel.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.877: "So you have dared, after all you have done, to put yourself in my power!" cried she.|"Well, you sha'n't escape me THIS time!"|And she took down a large knife and began to sharpen it.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.878: "Oh! dear mother, spare me!" shrieked Pinkel, falling on his knees, and looking wildly about him.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.879: "Spare you, indeed, you thief!|Where are my lantern and my goat?|No! not! there is only one fate for robbers!"|And she brandished the knife in the air so that it glittered in the firelight.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.880: "Then, if I must die," said Pinkel, who, by this time, was getting really rather frightened, "let me at least choose the manner of my death.|I am very hungry, for I have had nothing to eat all day.|Put some poison, if you like, into the porridge, but at least let me have a good meal before I die."	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.881: "That is not a bad idea," answered the woman;|"as long as you do die, it is all one to me."|And ladling out a large bowl of porridge, she stirred some poisonous herbs into it, and set about work that had to be done.|Then Pinkel hastily poured all the contents of the bowl into his bag, and make a great noise with his spoon, as if he was scraping up the last morsel.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.882: "Poisoned or not, the porridge is excellent.|I have eaten it, every scrap;|do give me some more," said Pinkel, turning towards her.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.883: "Well, you have a fine appetite, young man," answered the witch;|"however, it is the last time you will ever eat it, so I will give you another bowlful."|And rubbing in the poisonous herbs, she poured him out half of what remained, and then went to the window to call her cat.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.884: In an instant Pinkel again emptied the porridge into the bag, and the next minute he rolled on the floor, twisting himself about as if in agony, uttering loud groans the while.|Suddenly he grew silent and lay still.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.885: "Ah! I thought a second dose of that poison would be too much for you," said the witch looking at him.|"I warned you what would happen if you came back.|I wish that all thieves were as dead as you!|But why does not my lazy girl bring the wood I sent her for, it will soon be too dark for her to find her way?|I suppose I must go and search for her.|What a trouble girls are!"|And she went to the door to watch if there were any signs of her daughter.|But nothing could be seen of her, and heavy rain was falling.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.886: "It is no night for my cloak," she muttered;|"it would be covered with mud by the time I got back."|So she took it off her shoulders and hung it carefully up in a cupboard in the room.|After that she put on her clogs and started to seek her daughter.|Directly the last sound of the clogs had ceased, Pinkel jumped up and took down the cloak, and rowed off as fast as he could.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.887: He had not gone far when a puff of wind unfolded the cloak, and its brightness shed gleams across the water.|The witch, who was just entering the forest, turned round at that moment and saw the golden rays.|She forgot all about her daughter, and ran down to the shore, screaming with rage at being outwitted a third time.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.888: "Is that you, Pinkel?" cried she.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.889: "Yes, dear mother, it is I."	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.890: "Have you taken my gold cloak?"	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.891: "Yes, dear mother, I have."	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.892: "Are you not a great knave?"	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.893: "Yes, truly dear mother, I am."	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.894: And so indeed he was!	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.895: But, all the same, he carried the cloak to the king's palace, and in return he received the hand of the king's daughter in marriage.|People said that it was the bride who ought to have worn the cloak at her wedding feast;|but the king was so pleased with it that he would not part from it;|and to the end of his life was never seen without it.|After his death, Pinkel became king;|and let up hope that he gave up his bad and thievish ways, and ruled his subjects well.|As for his brothers, he did not punish them, but left them in the stables, where they grumbled all day long.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.896: Thorpe's Yule-Tide Stories.	Pinkel the Thief	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.897: The Adventures of a Jackal	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.898: by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.899: In a country which is full of wild beasts of all sorts there once lived a jackal and a hedgehog, and, unlike though they were, the two animals made great friends, and were often seen in each other's company.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.900: One afternoon they were walking along a road together, when the jackal, who was the taller of the two, exclaimed: "Oh! there is a barn full of corn;|let us go and eat some."	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.901: "Yes, do let us!" answered the hedgehog.|So they went to the barn, and ate till they could eat no more.|Then the jackal put on his shoes, which he had taken off so as to make no noise, and they returned to the high road.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.902: After they had gone some way they met a panther, who stopped, and bowing politely, said: "Excuse my speaking to you, but I cannot help admiring those shoes of yours.|Do you mind telling me who made them?"	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.903: "Yes, I think they are rather nice," answered the jackal;|"I made them myself, though."	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.904: "Could you make me a pair like them?" asked the panther eagerly.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.905: "I would do my best, of course," replied the jackal;|"but you must kill me a cow, and when we have eaten the flesh I will take the skin and make your shoes out of it."	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.906: So the panther prowled about until he saw a fine cow grazing apart from the rest of the herd.|He killed it instantly, and then gave a cry to the jackal and hedgehog to come to the place where he was.|They soon skinned the dead beasts, and spread its skin out to dry, after which they had a grand feast before they curled themselves up for the night, and slept soundly.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.907: Next morning the jackal got up early and set to work upon the shoes, while the panther sat by and looked on with delight.|At last they were finished, and the jackal arose and stretched himself.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.908: "Now go and lay them in the sun out there," said he;|"in a couple of hours they will be ready to put on;|but do not attempt to wear them before, or you will feel them most uncomfortable.|But I see the sun is high in the heavens, and we must be continuing our journey."	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.909: The panther, who always believed what everybody told him, did exactly as he was bid, and in two hours' time began to fasten on the shoes.|They certainly set off his paws wonderfully, and he stretched out his forepaws and looked at them with pride.|But when he tried to walk -- ah! that was another story!|They were so stiff and hard that he nearly shrieked every step he took, and at last he sank down where he was, and actually began to cry.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.910: After some time some little partridges who were hopping about heard the poor panther's groans, and went up to see what was the matter.|He had never tried to make his dinner off them, and they had always been quite friendly.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.911: "You seem in pain," said one of them, fluttering close to him, "can we help you?"	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.912: "Oh, it is the jackal!|He made me these shoes;|they are so hard and tight that they hurt my feet, and I cannot manage to kick them off."	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.913: "Lie still, and we will soften them," answered the kind little partridge.|And calling to his brothers, they all flew to the nearest spring, and carried water in their beaks, which they poured over the shoes.|This they did till the hard leather grew soft, and the panther was able to slip his feet out of them.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.914: "Oh, thank you, thank you," he cried, skipping round with joy.|"I feel a different creature.|Now I will go after the jackal and pay him my debts."|And he bounded away into the forest.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.915: But the jackal had been very cunning, and had trotted backwards and forwards and in and out, so that it was very difficult to know which track he had really followed.|At length, however, the panther caught sight of his enemy, at the same moment that the jackal had caught sight of him.|The panther gave a loud roar, and sprang forward, but the jackal was too quick for him and plunged into a dense thicket, where the panther could not follow.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.916: Disgusted with his failure, but more angry than ever, the panther lay down for a while to consider what he should do next, and as he was thinking, an old man came by.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.917: "Oh! father, tell me how I can repay the jackal for the way he has served me!"|And without more ado he told his story.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.918: "If you take my advice," answered the old man, "you will kill a cow, and invite all the jackals in the forest to the feast.|Watch them carefully while they are eating, and you will see that most of them keep their eyes on their food.|But if one of them glances at you, you will know that is the traitor."	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.919: The panther, whose manners were always good, thanked the old man, and followed his counsel.|The cow was killed, and the partridges flew about with invitations to the jackals, who gathered in large numbers to the feast.|The wicked jackal came amongst them;|but as the panther had only seen him once he could not distinguish him from the rest.|However, they all took their places on wooden seats placed round the dead cow, which was laid across the boughs of a fallen tree, and began their dinner, each jackal fixing his eyes greedily on the piece of meat before him.|Only one of them seemed uneasy, and every now and then glanced in the direction of his host.|This the panther noticed, and suddenly made a bound at the culprit and seized his tail;|but again the jackal was too quick for him, and catching up a knife he cut off his tail and darted into the forest, followed by all the rest of the party.|And before the panther had recovered from his surprise he found himself alone.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.920: "What am I to do now?" he asked the old man, who soon came back to see how things had turned out.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.921: "It is very unfortunate, certainly," answered he;|"but I think I know where you can find him.|There is a melon garden about two miles from here, and as jackals are very fond of melons they are nearly sure to have gone there to feed.|If you see a tailless jackal you will know that he is the one you want."|So the panther thanked him and went his way.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.922: Now the jackal had guessed what advice the old man would give his enemy, and so, while his friends were greedily eating the ripest melons in the sunniest corner of the garden, he stole behind them and tied their tails together.|He had only just finished when his ears caught the sound of breaking branches;|and he cried: "Quick! quick! here comes the master of the garden!"|And the jackals sprang up and ran away in all directions, leaving their tails behind them.|And how was the panther to know which was his enemy?	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.923: "They none of them had any tails," he said sadly to the old man, "and I am tired of hunting them.|I shall leave them alone and go and catch something for supper."	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.924: Of course the hedgehog had not been able to take part in any of these adventures;|but as soon as all danger was over, the jackal went to look for his friend, whom he was lucky enough to find at home.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.925: "Ah, there you are," he said gaily.|"I have lost my tail since I saw you last.|And other people have lost theirs too;|but that is no matter!|I am hungry, so come with me to the shepherd who is sitting over there, and we will ask him to sell us one of his sheep."	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.926: "Yes, that is a good plan," answered the hedgehog.|And he walked as fast as his little legs would go to keep up with the jackal.|When they reached the shepherd the jackal pulled out his purse from under his foreleg, and made his bargain.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.927: "Only wait till to-morrow," said the shepherd, "and I will give you the biggest sheep you ever saw.|But he always feeds at some distance from the rest of the flock, and it would take me a long time to catch him."	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.928: "Well, it is very tiresome, but I suppose I must wait," replied the jackal.|And he and the hedgehog looked about for a nice dry cave in which to make themselves comfortable for the night.|But, after they had gone, the shepherd killed one of his sheep, and stripped off his skin, which he sewed tightly round a greyhound he had with him, and put a cord round its neck.|Then he lay down and went to sleep.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.929: Very, very early, before the sun was properly up, the jackal and the hedgehog were pulling at the shepherd's cloak.|"Wake up," they said, "and give us that sheep.|We have had nothing to eat all night, and are very hungry."	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.930: The shepherd yawned and rubbed his eyes.|"He is tied up to that tree;|go and take him."|So they went to the tree and unfastened the cord, and turned to go back to the cave where they had slept, dragging the greyhound after them.|When they reached the cave the jackal said to the hedgehog.|"Before I kill him let me see whether he is fat or thin."	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.931: And he stood a little way back, so that he might the better examine the animal.|After looking at him, with his head on one side, for a minute or two, he nodded gravely.|"He is quite fat enough;|he is a good sheep."	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.932: But the hedgehog, who sometimes showed more cunning than anyone would have guessed, answered: "My friend, you are talking nonsense.|The wool is indeed a sheep's wool, but the paws of my uncle the greyhound peep out from underneath."	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.933: "He is a sheep," repeated the jackal, who did not like to think anyone cleverer than himself.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.934: "Hold the cord while I look at him," answered the hedgehog.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.935: Very unwillingly the jackal held the rope, while the hedgehog walked slowly round the greyhound till he reached the jackal again.|He knew quite well by the paws and tail that it was a greyhound and not a sheep, that the shepherd had sold them;|and as he could not tell what turn affairs might take, he resolved to get out of the way.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.936: "Oh! yes, you are right," he said to the jackal;|"but I never can eat till I have first drunk.|I will just go and quench my thirst from that spring at the edge of the wood, and then I shall be ready for breakfast."	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.937: "Don't be long, then," called the jackal, as the hedgehog hurried off at his best pace.|And he lay down under a rock to wait for him.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.938: More than an hour passed by and the hedgehog had had plenty of time to go to the spring and back, and still there was no sign of him.|And this was very natural, as he had hidden himself in some long grass under a tree!	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.939: At length the jackal guessed that for some reason his friend had run away, and determined to wait for his breakfast no longer.|So he went up to the place where the greyhound had been tethered and untied the rope.|But just as he was about to spring on his back and give him a deadly bite, the jackal heard a low growl, which never proceeded from the throat of any sheep.|Like a flash of lightning the jackal threw down the cord and was flying across the plain;|but though his legs were long, the greyhound's legs were longer still, and he soon came up with his prey.|The jackal turned to fight, but he was no match for the greyhound, and in a few minutes he was lying dead on the ground, while the greyhound was trotting peacefully back to the shepherd.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.940: Nouveaux Contes Berberes, par Rene Basset.	The Adventures of a Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.941: The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.942: by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.943: Now, though the jackal was dead, he had left two sons behind him, every whit as cunning and tricky as their father.|The elder of the two was a fine handsome creature, who had a pleasant manner and made many friends.|The animal he saw most of was a hyena;|and one day, when they were taking a walk together, they picked up a beautiful green cloak, which had evidently been dropped by some one riding across the plain on a camel.|Of course each wanted to have it, and they almost quarrelled over the matter;|but at length it was settled that the hyena should wear the cloak by day and the jackal by night.|After a little while, however, the jackal became discontented with this arrangement, declaring that none of his friends, who were quite different from those of the hyena, could see the splendour of the mantle, and that it was only fair that he should sometimes be allowed to wear it by day.|To this the hyena would by no means consent, and they were on the eve of a quarrel when the hyena proposed that they should ask the lion to judge between them.|The jackal agreed to this, and the hyena wrapped the cloak about him, and they both trotted off to the lion's den.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.944: The jackal, who was fond of talking, at once told the story;|and when it was finished the lion turned to the hyena and asked if it was true.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.945: "Quite true, your majesty," answered the hyena.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.946: "Then lay the cloak on the ground at my feet," said the lion, "and I will give my judgment."|So the mantle was spread upon the red earth, the hyena and the jackal standing on each side of it.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.947: There was silence for a few moments, and then the lion sat up, looking very great and wise.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.948: "My judgment is that the garment shall belong wholly to whoever first rings the bell of the nearest mosque at dawn to-morrow.|Now go;|for much business awaits me!"	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.949: All that night the hyena sat up, fearing lest the jackal should reach the bell before him, for the mosque was close at hand.|With the first streak of dawn he bounded away to the bell, just as the jackal, who had slept soundly all night, was rising to his feet.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.950: "Good luck to you," cried the jackal.|And throwing the cloak over his back he darted away across the plain, and was seen no more by his friend the hyena.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.951: After running several miles the jackal thought he was safe from pursuit, and seeing a lion and another hyena talking together, he strolled up to join them.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.952: "Good morning," he said;|"may I ask what is the matter?|You seem very serious about something."	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.953: "Pray sit down," answered the lion.|"We were wondering in which direction we should go to find the best dinner.|The hyena wishes to go to the forest, and I to the mountains.|What do you say?"	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.954: "Well, as I was sauntering over the plain, just now, I noticed a flock of sheep grazing, and some of them had wandered into a little valley quite out of sight of the shepherd.|If you keep among the rocks you will never be observed.|But perhaps you will allow me to go with you and show you the way?"	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.955: "You are really very kind," answered the lion.|And they crept steadily along till at length they reached the mouth of the valley where a ram, a sheep and a lamb were feeding on the rich grass, unconscious of their danger.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.956: "How shall we divide them?" asked the lion in a whisper to the hyena.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.957: "Oh, it is easily done," replied the hyena.|"The lamb for me, the sheep for the jackal, and the ram for the lion."	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.958: "So I am to have that lean creature, which is nothing but horns, am I?" cried the lion in a rage.|"I will teach you to divide things in that manner!"|And he gave the hyena two great blows, which stretched him dead in a moment.|Then he turned to the jackal and said: "How would you divide them?"	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.959: "Quite differently from the hyena," replied the jackal.|"You will breakfast off the lamb, you will dine off the sheep, and you will sup off the ram."	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.960: "Dear me, how clever you are!|Who taught you such wisdom?" exclaimed the lion, looking at him admiringly.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.961: "The fate of the hyena," answered the jackal, laughing, and running off at his best speed;|for he saw two men armed with spears coming close behind the lion!	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.962: The jackal continued to run till at last he could run no longer.|He flung himself under a tree panting for breath, when he heard a rustle amongst the grass, and his father's old friend the hedgehog appeared before him.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.963: "Oh, is it you?" asked the little creature;|"how strange that we should meet so far from home!"	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.964: "I have just had a narrow escape of my life," gasped the jackal, "and I need some sleep.|After that we must think of something to do to amuse ourselves."|And he lay down again and slept soundly for a couple of hours.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.965: "Now I am ready," said he;|"have you anything to propose?"	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.966: "In a valley beyond those trees," answered the hedgehog, "there is a small farmhouse where the best butter in the world is made.|I know their ways, and in an hour's time the farmer's wife will be off to milk the cows, which she keeps at some distance.|We could easily get in at the window of the shed where she keeps the butter, and I will watch, lest some one should come unexpectedly, while you have a good meal.|Then you shall watch, and I will eat."	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.967: "That sounds a good plan," replied the jackal;|and they set off together.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.968: But when they reached the farmhouse the jackal said to the hedgehog: "Go in and fetch the pots of butter and I will hide them in a safe place."	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.969: "Oh no," cried the hedgehog, "I really couldn't.|They would find out directly!|And, besides, it is so different just eating a little now and then."	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.970: "Do as I bid you at once," said the jackal, looking at the hedgehog so sternly that the little fellow dared say no more, and soon rolled the jars to the window where the jackal lifted them out one by one.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.971: When they were all in a row before him he gave a sudden start.|"Run for your life," he whispered to his companion;|"I see the woman coming over the hill!"|And the hedgehog, his heart beating, set off as fast as he could.|The jackal remained where he was, shaking with laughter, for the woman was not in sight at all, and he had only sent the hedgehog away because he did not want him to know where the jars of butter were buried.|But every day he stole out to their hiding-place and had a delicious feast.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.972: At length, one morning, the hedgehog suddenly said: "You never told me what you did with those jars?"	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.973: "Oh, I hid them safely till the farm people should have forgotten all about them," replied the jackal.|"But as they are still searching for them we must wait a little longer, and then I'll bring them home, and we will share them between us."	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.974: So the hedgehog waited and waited;|but every time he asked if there was no chance of getting jars of butter the jackal put him off with some excuse.|After a while the hedgehog became suspicious, and said: "I should like to know where you have hidden them.|To-night, when it is quite dark, you shall show me the place."	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.975: "I really can't tell you," answered the jackal.|"You talk so much that you would be sure to confide the secret to somebody, and then we should have had our trouble for nothing, besides running the risk of our necks being broken by the farmer.|I can see that he is getting disheartened, and very soon he will give up the search.|Have patience just a little longer."	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.976: The hedgehop said no more, and pretended to be satisfied;|but when some days had gone by he woke the jackal, who was sleeping soundly after a hunt which had lasted several hours.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.977: "I have just had notice," remarked the hedgehog, shaking him, "that my family wish to have a banquet to-morrow, and they have invited you to it.|Will you come?"	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.978: "Certainly," answered the jackal, "with pleasure.|But as I have to go out in the morning you can meet me on the road."	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.979: "That will do very well," replied the hedgehog.|And the jackal went to sleep again, for he was obliged to be up early.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.980: Punctual to the moment the hedgehog arrived at the place appointed for their meeting, and as the jackal was not there he sat down and waited for him.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.981: "Ah, there you are!" he cried, when the dusky yellow form at last turned the corner.|"I had nearly given you up!|Indeed, I almost wish you had not come, for I hardly know where I shall hide you."	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.982: "Why should you hide me anywhere?" asked the jackal.|"What is the matter with you?"	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.983: "Well, so many of the guests have brought their dogs and mules with them, that I fear it may hardly be safe for you to go amongst them.|No; don't run off that way," he added quickly, "because there is another troop that are coming over the hill.|Lie down here, and I will throw these sacks over you;|and keep still for your life, whatever happens."	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.984: And what did happen was, that when the jackal was lying covered up, under a little hill, the hedgehog set a great stone rolling, which crushed him to death.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.985: Contes Berberes.	The Adventures of the Jackal's Eldest Son	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.986: The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.987: by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.988: Now that the father and elder brother were both dead, all that was left of the jackal family was one son, who was no less cunning than the others had been.|He did not like staying in the same place any better than they, and nobody ever knew in what part of the country he might be found next.	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.989: One day, when we was wandering about he beheld a nice fat sheep, which was cropping the grass and seemed quite contented with her lot.	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.990: "Good morning," said the jackal, "I am so glad to see you.|I have been looking for you everywhere."	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.991: "For ME?" answered the sheep, in an astonished voice;|"but we have never met before!"	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.992: "No;|but I have heard of you.|Oh!|You don't know what fine things I have heard!|Ah, well, some people have all the luck!"	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.993: "You are very kind, I am sure," answered the sheep, not knowing which way to look.|"Is there any way in which I can help you?"	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.994: "There is something that I had set my heart on, though I hardly like to propose it on so short an acquaintance;|but from what people have told me, I thought that you and I might keep house together comfortably, if you would only agree to try.|I have several fields belonging to me, and if they are kept well watered they bear wonderful crops."	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.995: "Perhaps I might come for a short time," said the sheep, with a little hesitation;|"and if we do not get on, we can part company."	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.996: "Oh, thank you, thank you," cried the jackal;|"do not let us lose a moment."|And he held out his paw in such an inviting manner that the sheep got up and trotted beside him till they reached home.	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.997: "Now," said the jackal, "you go to the well and fetch the water, and I will pour it into the trenches that run between the patches of corn."|And as he did so he sang lustily.|The work was very hard, but the sheep did not grumble, and by-and-by was rewarded at seeing the little green heads poking themselves through earth.|After that the hot sun ripened them quickly, and soon harvest time was come.|Then the grain was cut and ground and ready for sale.	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.998: When everything was complete, the jackal said to the sheep: "Now let us divide it, so that we can each do what we like with his share."	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.999: "You do it," answered the sheep;|"here are the scales.|You must weigh it carefully."	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1000: So the jackal began to weigh it, and when he had finished, he counted out loud: "One, two, three, four, five, six, seven parts for the jackal, and one part for the sheep.|If she likes it she can take it, if not, she can leave it."	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1001: The sheep looked at the two heaps in silence -- one so large, the other so small;|and then she answered:	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1002: "Wait for a minute, while I fetch some sacks to carry away my share."	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1003: But it was not sacks that the sheep wanted;|for as soon as the jackal could no longer see her she set forth at her best pace to the home of the greyhound, where she arrived panting with the haste she had made.	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1004: "Oh, good uncle, help me, I pray you!" she cried, as soon as she could speak.	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1005: "Why, what is the matter?" asked the greyhound, looking up with astonishment.	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1006: "I beg you to return with me, and frighten the jackal into paying me what he owes me," answered the sheep.|"For months we have lived together, and I have twice every day drawn the water, while he only poured it into the trenches.|Together we have reaped our harvest;|and now, when the moment to divide our crop has come, he has taken seven parts for himself, and only left one for me."	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1007: She finished, and giving herself a twist, passed her woolly tail across her eyes;|while the greyhound watched her, but held his peace.|Then he said: "Bring me a sack."|And the sheep hastened away to fetch one.|Very soon she returned, and laid the sack down before him.	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1008: "Open it wide, that I may get in," cried he;|and when he was comfortably rolled up inside he bade the sheep take him on her back, and hasten to the place where she had left the jackal.	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1009: She found him waiting for her, and pretending to be asleep, though she clearly saw him wink one of his eyes.|However, she took no notice, but throwing the sack roughly on the ground, she exclaimed: "Now measure!"	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1010: At this the jackal got up, and going to the heap of grain which lay close by, he divided it as before into eight portions -- seven for himself and one for the sheep.	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1011: "What are you doing that for?" asked she indignantly.|"You know quite well that it was I who drew the water, and you who only poured it into the trenches."	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1012: "You are mistaken," answered the jackal.|"It was I who drew the water, and you who poured it into the trenches.|Anybody will tell you that!|If you like, I will ask those people who are digging there!"	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1013: "Very well," replied the sheep.	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1014: And the jackal called out: "Ho!|You diggers, tell me:|Who was it you heard singing over the work?"	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1015: "Why, it was you, of course, jackal!|You sang so loud that the whole world might have heard you!"	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1016: "And who it is that sings -- he who draws the water, or he who empties it?"	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1017: "Why, certainly he who draws the water!"	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1018: "You hear?" said the jackal, turning to the sheep.|"Now come and carry away your own portion, or else I shall take it for myself."	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1019: "You have got the better of me," answered the sheep;|"and I suppose I must confess myself beaten!|But as I bear no malice, go and eat some of the dates that I have brought in that sack."	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1020: And the jackal, who loved dates, ran instantly back, and tore open the mouth of the sack.|But just as he was about to plunge his nose in he saw two brown eyes calmly looking at him.|In an instant he had let fall the flap of the sack and bounded back to where the sheep was standing.	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1021: "I was only in fun;|and you have brought my uncle the greyhound.|Take away the sack, we will make the division over again."|And he began rearranging the heaps.	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1022: "One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, for my mother the sheep, and one for the jackal," counted he; casting timid glances all the while at the sack.	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1023: "Now you can take your share and go," said the sheep.|And the jackal did not need twice telling!|Whenever the sheep looked up, she still saw him flying, flying across the plain;|and, for all I know, he may be flying across it still.	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1024: Contes Berberes, par Rene Basset.	The Adventures of the Younger Son of the Jackal	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1025: The Three Treasures of the Giants	The Three Treasures of the Giants	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1026: by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Three Treasures of the Giants	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1027: Long, long ago, there lived an old man and his wife who had three sons;|the eldest was called Martin, the second Michael, while the third was named Jack.	The Three Treasures of the Giants	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1028: One evening they were all seated round the table, eating their supper of bread and milk.	The Three Treasures of the Giants	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1029: "Martin," said the old man suddenly, "I feel that I cannot live much longer.|You, as the eldest, will inherit this hut;|but, if you value my blessing, be good to your mother and brothers."	The Three Treasures of the Giants	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1030: "Certainly, father;|how can you suppose I should do them wrong?" replied Martin indignantly, helping himself to all the best bits in the dish as he spoke.|The old man saw nothing, but Michael looked on in surprise, and Jack was so astonished that he quite forgot to eat his own supper.	The Three Treasures of the Giants	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1031: A little while after, the father fell ill, and sent for his sons, who were out hunting, to bid him farewell.|After giving good advice to the two eldest, he turned to Jack.	The Three Treasures of the Giants	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1032: "My boy," he said, "you have not got quite as much sense as other people, but if Heaven has deprived you of some of your wits, it was given you a kind heart.|Always listen to what it says, and take heed to the words of your mother and brothers, as well as you are able!"|So saying the old man sank back on his pillows and died.	The Three Treasures of the Giants	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1033: The cries of grief uttered by Martin and Michael sounded through the house, but Jack remained by the bedside of his father, still and silent, as if he were dead also.|At length he got up, and going into the garden, hid himself in some trees, and wept like a child, while his two brothers made ready for the funeral.	The Three Treasures of the Giants	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1034: No sooner was the old man buried than Martin and Michael agreed that they would go into the world together to seek their fortunes, while Jack stayed at home with their mother.|Jack would have liked nothing better than to sit and dream by the fire, but the mother, who was very old herself, declared that there was no work for him to do, and that he must seek it with his brothers.	The Three Treasures of the Giants	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1035: So, one fine morning, all three set out;|Martin and Michael carried two great bags full of food, but Jack carried nothing.|This made his brothers very angry, for the day was hot and the bags were heavy, and about noon they sat down under a tree and began to eat.|Jack was as hungry as they were, but he knew that it was no use asking for anything;|and he threw himself under another tree, and wept bitterly.	The Three Treasures of the Giants	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1036: "Another time perhaps you won't be so lazy, and will bring food for yourself," said Martin, but to his surprise Jack answered:	The Three Treasures of the Giants	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1037: "You are a nice pair!|You talk of seeking your fortunes so as not to be a burden on our mother, and you begin by carrying off all the food she has in the house!"	The Three Treasures of the Giants	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
content.1038: This reply was so unexpected that for some moments neither of the brothers made any answer.|Then they offered their brother some of their food, and when he had finished eating they went their way once more.	The Three Treasures of the Giants	by Andrew Lang, 1906	The Orange Fairy Book
